A set $M$ with a law of composition $\sigma: M \times M \longrightarrow M$ is called a monoid if $\sigma$ is associative and $M$ admits a unit element with respect to $\sigma$.
Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension

The Galois group, or automorphism group, $\\[\operatorname{Aut}_{\mathbb{F}_q}(\mathbb{F}_{q'})\]$ of a finite field extension $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'} / \mathbb{F}_q\]$ is the group of field automorphisms of $\\[\mathbb{F}_{q'}\]$ that fix $\\[\mathbb{F}_q\]$. It is cyclic of order $n$, where $n$ is the degree of the extension.
Does the concept of a/an Monoid need to be defined for a definition of a/an Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of a Monoid involves a set with an associative binary operation and a unit element. A Monoid does not necessarily have to be a group since it does not require every element to have an inverse.

The concept of a Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension specifically refers to a group of automorphisms. This group is not just any set with a binary operation but a very specific type of group that has additional properties such as being cyclic and having inverses for each element, which are not required for monoids.

Therefore, understanding or defining a Monoid is not necessary for defining a Galois Group of a Finite Field Extension. The definition of a Galois Group inherently involves properties that go beyond those of a Monoid, specifically the requirement for every element to have an inverse, which is a property of groups but not monoids.
